WAR DEPARTMENT

Havana, Cuba,
Aug. 15, 1899.

Aristides Agramonte,
Cont. Surg.

Reports progress made
by him while at San-
tiago in the matter
of studying yellow
fever from a bacteri-
olgical standpoint.
States the check for
$100.00, about which he
wrote at Santiago, has
not been traced as
yet.

1st Indorsement.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
August 22, 1899.

Respectfully referred to Major
Walter Reed, Surgeon U.S. Army, Army
Medical Museum, to note.

G.M. Sternberg
Surgeon General, U.S. Army.

2nd Endorsement.
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM,
August 23, 1899.

Respectfully returned to the
Surgeon General, U.S. Army.
Contents noted.

Walter Reed,
Major & Surgeon, U.S. Army.
Received back, S.G.O. AUG 28 1899

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to George Miller Sternberg, August 15, 1899
div1.opener:
Las Animas Hospital
Havana Aug 15th 1899
To Brig. Gen. Geo. M. Sternberg
Surgeon General U.S.A.
Washington, D.C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
When I left Santiago on the
9th inst. there were but six cases of
yellow-fever in the hospital and none of
these was very seriously ill so that it
is not likely that many more deaths
will occur from this epidemic.

In all, I was enabled to make 388
cultures which arrived here without
breakage; these include those from twelve
autopsies of typical cases. The tissues
which I collected from these autopsies
will go to Washington in a day or two;
also a number of blood specimens in
glass bulbs for the agglutination test.

The general Order quarentining the
hospital did not allow me to send these
specimens from Santiago and I had
to obtain special permission from Dr.
Parker, Marine Hosp. Serv. to pass them without
the sterilization which would have ruined
them. I have treated the outside of the
vessels sufficiently to permit their safe
transportation.

I was very careful to select the blood
for the agglutination test from uncomplic-
ated cases of fever, and in two or three
instances I was enabled to confirm
this by subsequent post-mortem.

It was of great interest to me while
at Santiago to learn the frequency with
which the malarial organism was found
in undoubted cases of yellow-fever; I had
occasion to demonstrate it many times at
the hospital. It did not seem to affect
the usual run of the disease more than
to produce a sudden rise of the temperature
at irregular periods.

From ninecases of clear and uncom-
plicated yellow-fever, I took blood from
a vein of the elbow, puncturing it with
a platino-iridium needle fitted in a
sterilized glass tube of my design; it
was possible to obtain from 4 to 6 c.c. of
blood each time which was immediately
planted in a number of agar tubes. I have
excluded all possibility of contamination
and whatever organism develops must
necessarily have been present in the
blood of the individual.

Your note authorizing me to try
the “Convalescent's serum” experiments
reached me when I had already packed
to return, but will undertake them here
as soon as I can organize my work
which is about all I can handle
at present.

The check for $100.- regarding which
I wrote you from Santiago has not
been traced as yet, I hope you have
notified the Bank of its loss and ex-
pect to hear from your soon.
Believe me
div1.closer:
Very truly
Yours Aristides Agramonte A.A. Surg. U.S.A.
